children.name: to go swh or do sth very quickly
in a hurry
children.definition: /in a rush  if you do something in a hurry or in a rush, you do ittooquickly because you do not have much time, usually with the result that you makemistakes:

children.name: vội
examples: ▪ She had left in a hurry, and had forgotten her driver’s license.

children.name: be in a hurry/rush to do something
examples: ▪ We were in a hurry to get back to the office.
▪ Why are they in such a rush to sell the house?

children.name: rush
children.definition: 1 move quickly to move very quickly, especially because you need to be somewhere very soonSYN hurry:
examples: A small girl rushed past her.
Mo rushed off down the corridor.
2 rush to do somethingto do something very quickly and without delay :
I rushed to pack my suitcase before she came back.
He rushed to help his comrade.

children.name: hurry
children.definition: to go somewhere or do something more quickly than usual, for example because you are late or because you must finish sb by a particular time:
examples: If we hurry, we’ll get there in time.
I hate having to hurry a meal.
We’ll have to hurry, otherwise we’ll miss the start.
There’s no need to hurry. We’ve got plenty of time.
hurriedly[adv] written if you do sth hurriedly, you do it very quickly because you do not have much time: vội vàng , hối hả
He dressed hurriedly and went to answer the door.
The official hurriedly glanced through my papers and stamped my passport.
Sorry,’ Alice said, as she hurriedly put out her cigarette.

children.name: hurry to do something
examples: They were hurrying to catch their train.

children.name: hurry across/along/down etc
examples: She hurried down the corridor as fast as she could.

children.name: hurry after
examples: John hurried after his girlfriend.
hurry throughsthto hurry in order to finish sth in time, often so that you do not do sth properly:
She hurried through her breakfast with her eye on the clock.
People hurried through their morning chores, wanting to get to the fair.

children.name: dash
children.definition: to go somewhere very quickly, usually by running, especially because there is something important or urgent you must do:

children.name: dash around/out/into/across etc
examples: ▪ Kids were dashing across the playground chasing a ball.
▪ He just dashed into the office and then dashed out again without speaking to anyone.
▪ She dashed off to the airport and just managed to catch her plane.

children.name: dash to do something
examples: ▪ I dashed downstairs to answer the phone.

children.name: in haste
children.definition: especially written if you do something in haste, you do it too quickly and without taking enough care - used especially in literature:
examples: ▪ She had married in haste and regretted it ever since.
in your haste to do something
because you want to do something very quickly
▪ In his haste to leave, he almost forgot his coat.

children.name: to be in a situation in which you must hurry
be pushed for time
children.definition: be pushed/pressed for time to be in a situation when you must hurry because you do not have enough time for what you have to do: thời gian eo hẹp
examples: I don’t want to seem rude but I’m very pressed for time. Could I call you back later?
I can’t stop right now, I’m a little pushed for time.

children.name: be in a hurry
children.definition: I’m sorry, I’m in a hurry. I can’t stop now.
examples: Some people always seem to be in a hurry.

children.name: be in a hurry to do sth
examples: Would you like to stay for a coffee, or are you in a hurry to leave?

children.name: against the clock
children.definition: work/race  to work as quickly as you can because you only have a short time to finish something: chạy đua với thời gian
examples: ▪ In advertising you’re always working against the clock, trying to meet deadlines.

children.name: work/race against the clock to do something
examples: ▪ We really had to work against the clock to finish the report on time.

children.name: a race against time
children.definition: a situation in which you have to work extremely quickly, especially in order to do sth very important, because there is not much time to do it in: chạy đua với thời gian

children.name: Battleship repair crews swung into action in a race against time
examples: In an urgent race against time, the Coast Guard and marine biologists struggled to rescue a whale that had beached itself on the shore.

children.name: rush
children.definition: a situation in which you need to hurry:
examples: I knew there would be alast-minute rushto meet the deadline.
Don’t worry,there’s no rush. We don’t have to be at the station until 10.

children.name: do sth in a rush(= do something quickly because you need to hurry )
examples: I had to do my homework in a rush because I was late.

children.name: be in a rush
examples: I’m sorry, I can’t talk now – I’m in a rush.

children.name: hurry
children.definition: /rushB2  to make sb hurry, especially when you are impatient, and so that they do not have time to do sth carefully or properly: thúc dục , hối
examples: I wish you wouldn’t hurry me. I’m being as quick as I can.
I’m sorry to rush you, but we don’t have much time left.
Don’t rush me! You’ll only make me get it wrong.
Don’t hurry me. I’m doing this as fast as I can.

children.name: hurry sb into (doing) sth
examples: She doesn’t want to be hurried into making a decision.

children.name: hurry up
children.definition: hurry sb up thúc dục , bắt làm gấp
examples: They’re taking a long time to finish. Can you hurry them up a little?
I think she’s nearly finished packing. I’ll go hurry her up.

children.name: chivvy sb along
children.definition: informal to try to make someone do something more quickly, by repeatedly telling them to hurry: “rượt bắt”
examples: ▪ He’ll get the job done, but you need to chivvy him along a bit.

children.name: what you say to tell sb to hurry
come on
children.definition: say this when you want someone to hurry, especially when you areannoyedwith them for being too slow:
examples: ▪ Come on, you two, we’re going to be late.
▪ Oh come on! We don’t have all day!

children.name: hurry up
children.partOfSpeech: [intransitive phrasal verb not in progressive or past]
examples: ▪ Hurry up or you’ll be late for school.
▪ If you want tickets, you’d better hurry up. There’s only a few left.

children.name: hurry up and do something
examples: ▪ Hurry up and get your things, it’s time to go.

children.name: get a move on
children.definition: /get movingespecially US C2  spoken to start to do sth or go somewhere more quickly than before:
examples: Come on Sally, get a move on!
I think we’d better get moving, it’s only five minutes to boarding time.

children.name: get cracking
children.definition: UK spoken to start working quickly: mau lên nào
examples: ▪ Get cracking you people! I want the whole house cleaned by four o'clock.

children.name: get cracking doing sth
examples: ▪ When Alf arrives we’ll get cracking moving the furniture.

children.name: get cracking with
examples: ▪ It’s time you got cracking with your homework.

children.name: step on it
children.definition: say this when you want sb who is driving to hurry: lái nhanh lên
examples: ▪ Step on it. We have a plane to catch.
▪ You’ll have to step on it if you’re going to be there by eleven thirty.

children.name: jump to it
children.definition: UK spoken say this when you are ordering sb to do sth quickly:
examples: I need to have that job done before lunch. Come on, jump to it!

children.name: what you say to tell sb not to hurry
take your time
children.definition: say this when you want someone to do something more slowly and without hurrying, especially so that they do it carefully and properly: cứ thong thả, từ từ
examples: ▪ Take your time, think the matter over carefully, and then tell me what you’ve decided.
▪ Just take your time, and speak slowly and clearly.

children.name: there's no hurry
children.definition: there’s no hurry/there’s no rushB2  không cần vội
examples: ▪ There’s no hurry. The train never leaves on time.
▪ You can hand in your report any time next week. There’s no rush.

children.name: what's the hurry
children.definition: what’s the hurry?/ what’s the rush?B2  say this when sb is trying to do sth quickly and you do not think they need to hurry: sao phải vội
examples: ▪ What’s the hurry? The plane doesn’t leave for another two hours.

children.name: done quickly because you are hurrying
quick
children.definition: a quick look, meal, visit, decision etc is done very quickly, because you do not have much time:

children.name: nhanh
examples: ▪ Do I have time for a quick shower?
▪ Could I just make a quick phone call?
▪ The house is priced for a quick sale.

children.name: hurried
children.definition: done more quickly that usual, because you do not have much time
examples: ▪ After a hurried dinner, the boys do their homework or watch TV.
▪ They made a hurried search for the missing letters, but they couldn’t find them.
▪ Her handwriting looked shaky and hurried.
She ate a hurried breakfast in the cafe before catching her train.
We made a hurried departure.

children.name: hasty
children.definition: done very quickly and without much care or attention, because you have very little time: vội vàng
examples: ▪ He only had time for a hasty glance at the papers.
▪ ‘I have to go now,’ said Alex, bidding them a hasty goodbye.

children.name: frantic
children.definition: in a frantic situation, people are rushing around in a confused way, especially because they are worried that they will not have time to do sth or get sth: điên cuồng , cuống loạn
examples: I spent three frantic days trying to get everything ready.
frantic effort/attempt
Despite our frantic efforts, we were unable to save the boy’s life.
frantic pace/rush/haste etc
The staff spent three frantic days trying to get everything ready.
Throughout the night, everyone mopped floors and washed walls in a frantic effort to clean the place up for the inspectors.
Before the game there was a frantic rush to get the last few remaining tickets.
There was a frantic rush to escape from the building.
a day offrantic activity
afrantic searchfor her father
frantically[adv]
Mel was frantically trying to finish all her work before the deadline.
Hefrantically searchedfor the key.

children.name: feverish
children.definition: feverish activity/preparations/ haste etcwhen people are hurrying to finish something, in an excited way, and when there is not much time to do it in: “phát sốt”
examples: The show was about to begin and behind the stage there were scenes of feverish activity.
Feverish preparations were being made for the arrival of the President.

children.name: rush job
children.definition: a  informal a piece of work that is done too quickly and therefore not as well as it should be done, especially because there is not enough time:
examples: I don’t want a rush job. I want this work done right.
Getting back into condition after a serious injury can’t be a rush job.

children.name: rushed
children.definition: sth that is rushed is done very quickly, often too quickly to do it carefully or properly; sb who is rushed does things very quickly, often so that it is not done carefully or properly:
examples: People have complained that the doctors seem rushed, with too many patients to see in a day.
The actors’ performances were needlessly rushed.

children.name: be in no hurry/not be in any hurry
children.definition: to not be in a hurry, because you have plenty of time:
examples: ▪ I’m in no hurry. I can wait.
▪ He wasn’t in any hurry, so he decided to take a look around town.
be in no hurry/not be in any hurry to do something
be very slow to do something, perhaps too slow
▪ Danny seemed in no hurry to pay me the money he owed me

children.name: unhurried
children.definition: done slowly and calmly, without hurrying:
examples: ▪ He swam gracefully, with easy, unhurried strokes.
▪ It’s a community of old trees, big houses, and an unhurried life.
▪ She walked along, calm and unhurried.

children.name: leisurely
children.definition: a leisurely activity or way of doing something is pleasantly slow and relaxed, and done without hurrying:
examples: ▪ She enjoyed a leisurely breakfast and had time to read the newspaper.
▪ The horse walked at a leisurely pace through the flat Fenland countryside.

children.name: throw
children.definition: verbthrew,thrownMOVE QUICKLY

children.name: rush
children.definition: nounHURRY

children.name: If you do something like mad, you do it very enthusiastically, quickly or a lot
examples: _She's been saving like mad because she wants to buy a car.

children.name: accelerate
children.definition: verb
